centralQuestion: Should West Virginia diversify its economy away from coal by subsidizing green industries?

reasons.description: Catalyze new industry clusters and leverage large federal funding flows (e.g., IRA/IIJA) to transform coal-dependent regions.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'Catalyzing a ‘just transition’ from coal to clean energy in West Virginia’s Coalfields'
PBS NewsHour: 'Biden makes $450M available for clean energy projects at coal mines'

reasons.description: Reduce economic risk by diversifying away from a structurally declining coal sector.

sources.title: Energy Information Administration: 'West Virginia State Energy Profile'
Reuters: 'Trump's push for a comeback in coal may turn to ashes'

reasons.description: Deliver public health, land-reuse, and community fairness benefits through 'just transition' policies that support workers and coalfield communities.

sources.title: Resources for the Future: 'Enabling Fairness for Energy Workers and Communities in the Energy Transition (Synthesis Report)'

reasons.description: Create concrete local manufacturing jobs via clean-energy projects (e.g., Weirton long-duration battery factory).

sources.title: The Guardian: 'A renewable energy battery plant will rise in US where a steel mill once stood'

objections.description: Subsidies constitute industrial policy that picks winners, risking waste, distortion, and larger deficits.

sources.title: American Enterprise Institute: 'Industrial policy and deficits: Dark clouds for democratic capitalism'

objections.description: Large green projects (e.g., hydrogen hubs) face uncertainty, delays, and execution risks; promised jobs may not materialize on schedule.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Explainer: What are Hydrogen Hubs and why are they raising hackles?'

objections.description: State incentive packages risk cronyism and expose taxpayers if projects underperform or fail.

sources.title: Associated Press (AP): 'Bill signed for West Virginia renewable energy battery plant'

objections.description: Coal still underpins grid reliability and employment in key areas; rapid diversification could threaten energy security and local economies.

sources.title: Politico: 'Amid decline, coal seeks new champions in Washington'

research.title: Energy Policy: 'Coal communities' views on local economic futures'
research.description: Peer-reviewed study examining how coal-dependent communities assess their economic options amid energy transition policies, highlighting preferences, perceived risks, and support conditions for diversification; abstract publicly accessible.

research.title: Energy Research & Social Science: 'Adaptation, culture, and the energy transition in American coal country'
research.description: Peer-reviewed analysis of socio-economic adaptation processes in U.S. coal country, discussing cultural factors and policy mechanisms that shape transitions and diversification; abstract publicly accessible.

research.title: Energy Research & Social Science: 'Advocating a just transition in Appalachia: Civil society and politics in regional energy transition'
research.description: Peer-reviewed article focused on central Appalachia (including West Virginia) assessing how civil society actors and policies promote renewable industries and just transition strategies; abstract publicly accessible.

research.title: Structural Change and Economic Dynamics: 'Energy transitions and labor market patterns in the U.S. coal mining region'
research.description: Peer-reviewed econometric study of how coal employment changes affect wages and sectoral labor outcomes across coal-producing states, informing diversification policy design; abstract publicly accessible.

research.title: Energy Research & Social Science: 'Assessing county-level vulnerability to the energy transition in the United States'
research.description: Peer-reviewed work mapping economic vulnerability of U.S. counties (including Appalachian coal regions) to the energy transition, offering insights for targeted, place-based support; abstract publicly accessible.
